dialogue.text: *spreading ancient maps* Every explorer thought they were mapping new territory, but look—they all drew the same coastline of mystery from different angles. The unknown has a shape.

*finger following paths* 'What am I?' is like that—not a destination on any map but the compass itself. *comparing charts* Every seeker's journey looks different, but we're all circumnavigating the same mystery. *placing compass on map* The question doesn't point to answers—it points to true north of being.
*overlaying transparencies* When you stack all these maps, the individual paths disappear but the pattern remains. Everyone's been sailing around the same central void.

*watching needle quiver* Because 'What am I?' isn't leading us somewhere—it's keeping us oriented while we explore. *spinning compass* Every direction leads back to the question, every journey circles this central not-knowing. *profound acceptance* The compass that always points to mystery is more valuable than any map to certainty. We're not lost—we're circumnavigating ourselves. The journey IS the destination.

psychological_notes: 'What am I?' as compass rather than map—providing orientation without destination. All seekers circumnavigating same central mystery. Being lost with good compass better than found with wrong map.
